Incidentally, this was also how I felt live watching her initial crappy maze design that drove my OCD crazy. Thankfully, her final result turned out pretty nice!

Since no one likes gatekeeping during live chat, I'll remind folks here: please stop spamming "Hey Moona!" meme out of context or intrusively bringing up Moona's name over and over in Pekora's live chat. When Moona logs into the Minecraft server for the first time (NOT when Moona's simply relogging to avoid sleeping at night) or when Pekora and Moona greet and interact with each other, feel free to shout "Hey Moona!" all you want--I do it, too! When Pekora's stuck on some complicated redstone piston automation concept, feel free to suggest asking Moona's help, but if Pekora is not responding to that recommendation and intends to solve the problems herself, please respect that. I'd like to believe most of you guys are simply having fun and "harmlessly" memeing, but frankly the spam has become bothersome.

It has literally gotten to the point where it's becoming annoying seeing the spam. 

That said, what you or I say matters little in the end, for as long as the streamer in question, Pekora in this case, continues to respond to such calls, validating the aforementioned spammer.

@Amadeus Aye, that cool-off is ultimately what I'd want to avoid seeing, because I actually enjoy Pekora and Moona's interactions.
Moona has also hinted it on Twitter that she only wants to hear "Hey Moona!" when it comes to Pekora herself, not from Moona's live chat spams:
Is it really that hard to get new jokes? Like it's just so tiring with this and like how much you see "ara ara" and all the other garbage that we''ve already seen before plenty of times.

@AHHHEYGAO yes, those Hey Moona spam is so annoying, i started to report and block them. They are just going to ruin the natural interaction between them and ultimately lead to the cool-off as you said. The funniest content is the natural interactions, not the forced one.

@AHHHEYGAO Of course, Pekora could easily embrace the meme like how Rushia does with her pettanko spam, but judging from her self-conscious greetings to Moona - erasing the hey and replacing it with hello - just screams social awkwardness (and the discomfort (?) of having to fulfill her fans'  expectations).
You are not gatekeeping, THEY ARE backseating. I believe their exposure to english audience have reached the kids. It's very common on twitch, number one cancers in all streaming platforms.
@Amadeus  yea...The Hey Moona is so forcibly that i almost found it not funny anymore...
@Tyjones D Lol, twitch chat at least knows what's going on and stays on topic most of the time. And the emote spam is better than the constant "boing boing" and "hey moona" spam.

@Amadeus Moona already got tired of the spam and told people that she only likes it when Pekora says it. But her relationship with her audience is different, but not necessarily a bad way

But Pekora is very protective of her  audience, she only lays the hammer when it affects other people like nousagis spamming Peko in other streams or that nasty prank, tricking her into  believing that flare was injured

@Eduardo Hernández Not to point fingers, but most of the Hey Moona-ing came from users with roman characters, meaning they were more likely foreign viewers (of course, I might just not be able to recognize Hey Moona in Japanese - if so, please correct me). Thus, the additional language barrier might also play a non-insignificant role in whether Pekora were to actually decide to do something about this - after all, being the person that I think she is, I doubt she could easily scold her audience, moreso when differences in language might cause unwanted misunderstanding.

Dammit, I was in the "stop telling people what to do" camp, but people are really overdoing it. And it's the same with Rushia's pettanko joke. It's been overused to the point of being annoying, when literally EVERYONE constantly spams a meme, with complete disregard to the content on screen.

@Amadeus Normally I'd use something like the text (and usernames) as a rough indicator of demographics, but in this specific instance I don't think that's reliable since the original meme was in simple English and that even Japanese viewers would be typing it in English.
